reasoning:
The critique targets a real supporting step in the paper’s case: Section 3.3’s claim that (difference-making) bounded views that aggregate goods/bads separately are “fussy” because even an extremely tiny fraction of “bad” resource-use can block a mostly-great future. That’s relevant but not load-bearing for the whole ‘no easy eutopia’ thesis (which also leans on linear/unbounded arguments, fat tails, multiplicative fragility, etc.), so centrality is moderate.

However, the critique overstates the extent to which the paper’s conclusion turns on an “arbitrary” unit like star-systems. In the paper, the star-count is mostly an illustrative way to represent an enormous resource base; under the stipulated separate-aggregation setup (global summing of bads before applying a saturating transform) the worry is essentially scale: if the accessible domain is huge, even tiny fractions can correspond to large absolute bads, and whether that pushes you past some disvalue-saturation threshold depends on the curvature/bounds that were already partly fixed by assumptions like ‘common-sense utopia is mostly-great.’ So “change the grain and the conclusion flips” isn’t generally right given their modeling assumptions; it flips only if you change substantive composition/aggregation assumptions, not mere units.

Still, the critique correctly notes that the paper’s numerical ‘1/10^22’ style argument is conditional on substantive assumptions about how disvalue composes across space (additivity prior to bounding, comparability across regions, no quarantine/local saturation, etc.), and that the paper would need to defend those assumptions (or show robustness across alternatives). Hence moderate correctness and some (but limited) weakening strength.
title: "Arbitrary moral grain size undermines catastrophe claim"
